Text: A British CO2 tax will result in unfair competition conditions. If British producers are subjected to taxes while foreign producers are not, it will mean that other countries can produce more cheaply than British producers, and then we will import more instead, which will have the opposite effect. If import duties are imposed on goods from abroad, it will no longer be as attractive to export to us.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax calculated in relation to the climate impact of goods and energy is the most cost-effective way to get businesses and consumers to make greener choices. A uniform CO2 tax will be easy to administer and will be a good way to support the market in finding greener solutions and products itself, rather than letting politicians try to control it with the obvious challenges that can bring. A uniform CO2 tax, calculated according to climate impact, will be fair and clarify the difference between green and black energy and products.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most will create an economic incentive to choose greener alternatives. When the most polluting products become more expensive, both consumers and producers will have reason to change habits and production. It is an effective way to reduce emissions, while the revenues can be used for green investments.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax on groceries and energy will affect ALL segments of the population—and for those who already struggle to make ends meet, it will mean that it becomes even harder to afford healthy food and the necessary heating, lighting, and electricity for essential appliances. It doesn’t help if we try to create a better world in the future (because of lower CO2 emissions) for our children and young people, if their lives are already ruined in early childhood due to poor or insufficient food and lack of heat.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax on groceries and energy will end up affecting those who already have the least. It should not be fair that an ordinary family has to pay the price, regardless of whether you have a high or low income. It will only make everyday life more expensive without necessarily ensuring significant effects on the climate. Instead, more time should be spent on green technologies and NOT on punishing everyday consumption habits.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax on groceries and energy will likely affect low-income families, who spend a larger portion of their monthly income on food and various necessities. Social inequality in society will increase by making it more expensive to live, without necessarily reducing CO2 emissions significantly. Instead, the focus should be on green technologies and sustainable initiatives as well as alternatives.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text:
A CO2 tax on groceries could serve three purposes.
1) There will—depending on the size of the tax—be a reduced consumption of the affected goods, which will decrease CO2 emissions.
2) It is goods from the top luxury shelf that will be affected, which will lessen the impact of a tax on lower income groups.
3) The tax will contribute to the society’s household budget and can be used for other CO2 activities that can reduce emissions.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax should be introduced on the groceries that pollute the most, because our planet is in crisis, and it is important to help wherever we can. If we can use the money generated from the CO2 tax to plant trees or help clean up the oceans, it would have a positive impact on the nature of our planet. In this way, we can put a stop to global warming (and thus our planet’s suffering) before it is too late. We can help ensure a better world for future generations. It would be a benefit for everyone, even though it would be difficult for some.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most will be effective in relation to Brits’ climate footprint by: a. Positively changing consumption patterns in relation to agriculture’s CO2 emissions and environmental impact by reducing Brits’ consumption of meat. Less meat and more vegetables will also have a positive effect on peoples’ health and therefore on society’s healthcare costs. b. It will also affect net consumption and limit our depletion of the earth’s resources.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Aid to other countries should not be reduced, as it helps these countries reach a higher level, especially in terms of education, and thus, in the long run, they become better able to manage on their own. And the higher the population’s level of education, the more independent and self-sufficient they will become. Therefore, in the long term, there will be no need for support.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: All taxes imposed on citizens usually affect those who cannot afford them. It sounds promising that we should all drive electric cars to reduce CO2, but for those of us who do not have the income to invest in such a car, it is impossible. We then have to use public transport instead, but where I live, there are hardly any buses, so what am I supposed to do? Then we are supposed to heat our houses with heat pumps to reduce emissions. I rent, and the landlord will not invest in it, and I cannot/will not pay, since it is not my house. So I am forced to use extremely expensive wood pellets.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: An argument against the government introducing CO2 taxes on food and energy is that competitiveness may be weakened, which could lead to economic consequences for several British national companies (especially agriculture). Companies may choose to move production to another country where energy and food production have lower taxes or lower climate ambitions (carbon leakage), and therefore it could hit, for example, British farmers economically hard, and it could have a negative effect where it could actually increase global CO2 emissions.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: As I personally fear what, for example, Russia might do, I simply believe that the UK should be much more independent, and that the UK should do whatever is possible so that we can become self-sufficient in, for example, electricity, gas, etc., but of course without this harming our animal and plant life.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: As a general rule, I don't think one should simply provide something without the recipient giving something in return, such as work, democracy, or another form of compensation, for example better working conditions, so that we are not just giving and thereby possibly also contributing to unfair competition from the recipient country, for instance if they supply goods produced by child labor or similar practices.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: As a humanist, I believe that it is a moral obligation to help those who are displaced by war and persecution. The UK has a strong tradition of social welfare and a strong commitment to human rights. British church organizations and a number of private charities have long fought to welcome refugees, help them integrate into society, and provide them with basic security of life.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: As long as society needs oil and gas, it will be an advantage to be independent of these products from Russia or Middle Eastern countries. Of course, the goal is that we should not use oil and gas in the future, but as long as alternatives have not been implemented, it is unfortunately a necessity.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: As we have all been hearing for many years now, CO2 is terrible for our atmosphere and has had, and will continue to have, a major impact on global warming. Therefore, I believe that we should do what we can to reduce the amount of CO2 that is being produced. If a tax on the groceries and energy sources that are the worst offenders in terms of CO2 emissions can have a positive impact or help reduce the amount of CO2 released into the atmosphere, then why not do it?
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: As we still have to buy gas from Russia, the government should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea. By buying gas from Russia, we support Russia’s economy, and this is contrary to the agreements on sanctions against Russia adopted after Russia’s attack on Ukraine on February 24, 2022, and the ongoing warfare.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Asylum seekers fleeing from war or persecution should be accepted, as this could easily happen to us here in the UK. What you wish for yourself, you should also wish for your loved ones. It is incredibly hard to leave your family, friends, and the life you have for a better future. I think we should be understanding.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: At the moment, energy from sun, wind, and water is what most politicians want to promote, almost at any cost. That is, to some extent, reasonable enough. But if you follow energy prices hour by hour, you also find out where the electricity comes from. Sun, wind, and water usually supply us with between 60-85%, less at night. The rest is then supplemented with electricity produced from fossil fuels. As the world looks today, the government must ensure that we produce the oil we need ourselves for many years to come. Otherwise, we are dependent on countries that, as is clearly the case, we do not know whether are friend or foe.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: At the present time, we are in no way energy independent. We are in a situation where we do not know how the wars will end, or what the outcome of the wars will be. Therefore, it is about securing ourselves as much as possible. The North Sea is a huge opportunity and has already been utilized, and that is why we should also extract more there.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
Based on the current uncertain "world order" and political instability in relation to both allies and totalitarian states, Europe, and thus also the UK, should maintain and strengthen all critical societal functions, unfortunately including a regional supply of oil and gas at a level that can cover the most important societal functions.

Therefore, the government should work towards oil and gas production in the North Sea that, in a balanced manner, can at all times ensure critical supply security. This will therefore not necessarily lead to an increase in production.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Because we already pay WAY, WAY, WAY too much for everything and to others. It’s more than our society can handle, as schools/institutions, care centers, and the healthcare system LACK resources, and our holidays are being removed and the retirement age is being raised (BUT NOT for those who already have FAR TOO MUCH, and who almost "steal" our money).
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Behavior regulation through pricing is the best way to make consumers reflect on their actions. Eating meat daily because it has been unbelievably cheap, and thus polluting more, should come at a cost. 500 grams of beef should never be cheaper than vegetables. The increased tax should go directly to climate research and green solutions. There should be a lower tax on British vegetables and fruit.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: By entering this area with British know-how, technology, economy, and ethical values, we will be able to help create greater independence from, for example, Russian, Eastern, and Middle Eastern countries' fossil resources. I know that fossil fuels pollute, but I believe that if WE extract it, we have a greater opportunity to influence the way we extract and handle it. Right now, we are fully playing by their rules and have very limited influence on their handling and extraction of the material.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: By regulating oil and gas extraction in the North Sea, we will eventually achieve energy independence, so purchases from other countries can be reduced to a minimum of expenses, thereby promoting our own revenues for other projects within renewable energy, both on land and at sea. That’s worth considering as well, don’t you think?
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: By targeting exactly the products that pollute the most, consumers can play a greater role in reducing emissions. There will be an opportunity to completely opt out of the major climate offenders based solely on the price of the product. Right now, there is a tendency for people to avoid beef because of the price. Brits are very much guided by their wallets, and if they can save money somewhere, they do. Therefore, it would be attractive to exempt vegetables from VAT.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Cheaper oil and gas will mean that everything becomes cheaper, from taxes to food, and then there will be money for higher wages. A wealthy society benefits and brings joy to everyone in British society. Transporting food to British supermarkets currently has high transportation costs, which in the future will become cheaper, and this will lower costs so that all goods in supermarkets become cheaper.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Conversations with Africans from various countries have shown that Africa is the world’s richest continent, and the only reason that many of the countries are not self-sufficient is that they are governed by kleptocrats who steal all the aid the West sends as development assistance. It turns out that certain countries have managed to do well and have a strong economy and significant foreign trade.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Development aid is an important initiative for raising the welfare and development of the entire world. Imagine that each country is a link in a long chain. If one link is weakened, the whole chain is weakened. The problems will not be limited to the individual country, but will spread to affluent countries like the UK—for example, in the form of climate refugees and political refugees. By helping other countries, we not only show compassion and care, but also build bonds across borders. New collaborations will arise, and we can learn from each other’s cultures.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Development aid should be reduced, as there are many countries that exploit it and pocket the money themselves. So perhaps we should look at which countries actually use the money in the right way, as intended—and those countries that do not live up to this should lose their opportunity for development aid.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Energy extraction should be temporarily strengthened until there is clarity about the consequences of "green energy." This will reduce dependence in the long term. We will have time to do the groundwork properly and ensure that money is not wasted. As it is now, no one has an overview of the projects. We can see today that there is criticism of the interplay between wind and solar.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Energy independence is of crucial importance now and in the future, as a supplement to increased use of renewable energy, which is—and will be—of a fluctuating nature. This is with the aim of avoiding unwanted political pressure from hostile regimes. Security of supply and the nation’s self-determination take precedence over other considerations. In this way, geopolitically induced pressures can be effectively rejected without compromising security policy concerns.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Expenditures on development aid must be reduced due to the widespread corruption among the recipients. The money is being misused by those in power. This often leads to the oppression of populations. In order to retain power, the corrupt rulers often resort to violence, even murder of those who try to expose them. In the worst case, this can lead to attempted coups and thus war.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Far too much aid money ends up in the wrong hands—and is NOT used to improve the lives of the poor. Only if British people follow the flow of money (the aid) all the way to the end users (the poor), will I change my viewpoint. We have just seen in Gaza how emergency aid is dropped from planes. This aid is collected by gangs, and the locals fight over the leftovers—and kill each other to get a piece of the "cake."
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Far too much money is spent on development aid. A great deal of the money never reaches where the need is! Far too much goes to administration, corrupt and thieving "middlemen," and the people in need receive only a fraction of the help. At the same time as pouring lots of money into development support, our own pensioners—who helped lay the foundations of our SO-CALLED welfare society—are being starved :(
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: First and foremost, we can point out that even here in the UK we are facing our own economic challenges, and that there are several things that are simply not working. This includes the healthcare system, where there are long waiting lists and sometimes examinations are not thorough enough. In addition, elderly care is also notably under pressure. Nursing homes, home care, etc.—the elderly are not getting the life they should, the food they should, the care they should, or the time that should be spent on them. They have contributed to society their whole lives, and then in their final years they receive care that is completely unacceptable.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: First of all, I have no idea what the money is supposed to be used for or where it actually ends up, if not in the state’s tax revenue. Secondly, I don’t believe that a tax will change CO2 emissions. Thirdly, a tax seems to me like a kind of indulgence: I have paid—my conscience is clear. Once people have a conviction about something, it is very difficult to change their position, as many see it as a defeat. In addition to the established CO2 emissions, there are so many other factors that affect the climate. The other day it was reported that efforts to achieve cleaner air have led to fewer clouds.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: First of all, they have many children; the more there are, the more money is needed. We have elderly people here at home who cannot get help. We can't help the whole world; they have to do something themselves. People don't learn to manage on their own. The wars going on around the world need to be stopped. I think things would go better if women were allowed to decide.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: For many years to come, we will need oil and gas. We should not be dependent on Russia or other countries. In addition, it creates a lot of jobs. What about CO2? We have found a solution to that, simply by pumping it back underground into the old wells. CO2 storage will also create many jobs.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
For our health, for our children, for the sake of future generations, for the existence of the planet.
For all life, for our food, so that we, our children, and all future generations can have a good life throughout their entire lives from birth to death without diseases caused by inhaling polluted air and by allergies.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: For several years now, I have heard that we need to phase out natural gas/oil and use alternative energy. Gas/oil is to be removed from the shelves in 2032. Then what? District heating uses gas/oil. If they weren’t there, the radiators would be lukewarm. We can spend money on all sorts of studies, but things take time. It is true that we need to move away from polluting energy sources. We are just not ready yet and haven’t invented the right solution yet either. Instead of spending X million on expensive forecasts, use the money on ideas for alternative energy and set an achievable timeline.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: For the sake of the future. It’s not about you, but about those who come after us. Think of your children and grandchildren. And of their children. Should they have to go without clean water and live on artificially produced food because you couldn’t restrain yourself during your lifetime? So don’t do it for yourself—you won’t gain anything from that. But do it for others—it means a lot.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text:
For various reasons, I do not think the government should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence:
1) Firstly, we know that oil and natural gas are fossil energy sources that negatively affect nature. 2) Secondly, in the UK we are KNOWN for green and renewable energy — energy from wind, water, sun, etc. These energy sources are FREE, less harmful to the environment, and renewable! While fossil fuels will eventually be depleted — and thus become more expensive the more they are used up — renewable energy is natural and will, over time, cause energy prices to fall for everyone!
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Foreign aid is equivalent to military aid. If foreign aid is not provided, people remain uneducated, hungry, and unable to feed themselves. Only through possible foreign aid can people be informed about the importance of learning to feed themselves and their children. In this way, they can also learn about hygiene and proper nutrition for children.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Governments should not promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea. At a time of global focus on climate goals and energy transition, the unstable prices of fossil fuels are at odds with the global emphasis on sustainable development. Extraction in the North Sea would harm fragile marine ecosystems and have a negative impact on fisheries and biodiversity. By investing in renewable energy sources such as wind and solar, we can create a long-term green energy future.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Groceries and energy are already expensive enough in the UK. Many other countries pollute more than we do, so why should we be punished with more expensive goods and more expensive energy? We often sell our green electricity to other countries, which means we ourselves have to pay more for electricity. It makes no sense, and there is no reason to make it even more expensive to be British.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I am against refugees. the UK should take in fewer refugees. We should refuse to let refugees come and live with us. Refugees are of no use to society. They commit many crimes. I am against accepting refugees in our country. The UK should completely ban refugees from entering the country.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I am convinced that we should investigate and implement nuclear power plants, especially the smaller ones, as they cause less damage in the event of a leak. Based on the knowledge we have today about pollution and CO2, I am convinced that nuclear power plants are the right choice if the Earth is to "survive." If we, as a country, can accomplish this, it will be possible to export our knowledge to the other countries—so they cannot say, "we want to pollute just as much as you in the West have done." Therefore, no to oil and gas extraction.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I am mostly afraid that development funds end up in the wrong pockets, including corruption, and will therefore refrain from arguing for development aid. I lean much more towards development within our own country—in fact, not just reducing aid but pretty much stopping it altogether.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I believe it is important that we all take a stand, and we do that when it affects our wallets. That’s when we start to think—even those who have money. If we don’t all help, there will never be a better world. I think we can go far if we all contribute something. After all, we can choose not to buy if we feel it isn’t necessary.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I believe it is important. Firstly: A CO2 tax makes it more expensive to consume goods and energy with a high climate impact. This motivates both consumers and producers to switch to greener alternatives – such as electric cars, organic foods, or renewable energy. Secondly: It creates an economic incentive for green innovation. Because when polluting solutions become more expensive, it becomes economically more attractive for companies to invest in sustainable technologies, as well as to develop CO2-neutral products and focus on energy optimization.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I believe it is too easy to cheat with evidence that one is persecuted or in danger. We should not have more Muslim refugees – they will always be persecuted because they have to live according to an outdated Quranic law. People from Palestine are so indoctrinated with revenge against Europeans that they will never fit into our world.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I believe that a CO2 tax is necessary to protect our environment and future generations. Although it may seem like an extra expense now, it is an investment in a cleaner planet. We are already seeing the consequences of climate change, and we need to act. A tax can motivate companies to find greener solutions and encourage us as consumers to make more sustainable choices. It is about taking responsibility for the world we leave to our children and grandchildren. It is a small price to pay for a healthier future for all of us.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I believe that a CO2 tax should be introduced because the products that pollute the most are not essential for life—on the contrary, it is often these products that lead to unhealthy lifestyle-related diseases. By introducing a CO2 tax, it is possible to achieve a healthier society as a positive effect of the primary desired effect: reduced CO2 emissions.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I believe that especially with regard to Africa, in all the years I have been alive — and probably even before — we have been helping, but nothing has really happened. Not all emergency aid reaches those in need either; it can be stolen, and then those who need it have to buy it instead of receiving it. There are many agricultural machines standing unused, either because we haven’t taught them how to repair them, or because the Africans don’t care.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I believe that governments should introduce a carbon tax on the most polluting goods and energy sources in order to reduce emissions. The climate crisis requires swift action. Introducing a carbon tax on highly polluting goods can quickly reduce emissions and help achieve the goal of limiting global warming.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text:
I believe that it is necessary for us as individuals and as a society to take responsibility for the climate changes we are facing.
It will help many people act in a more climate-friendly way if we make some foods cheaper and others more expensive.
Therefore, I see it as common sense to introduce a CO2 tax where the pollution is greatest.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I believe that it will be better for both the refugees and the UK if the refugees are helped in their local area. It is easier to manage that effort economically, and it also reduces cultural, social, and religious pressure on British society. Finally, the population groups who are fleeing can remain in their own cultural and religious area and continue their struggle there instead of in the UK.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I believe that the UK is a country with a high standard of living, a high level of education, knowledge, and resources among the population. There is a high quality of life in the UK, and everyone can get help in difficult situations. We have freedom of speech and a high level of information. There is great unrest and much suffering in the world. We ought to be able to help and support where there is need. Currently, for example, by providing aid to sick children in Gaza. Naturally, we must also keep our own safety in mind in the projects we participate in.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I believe that the UK should be independent of others and able to take care of itself in a world that is so changeable. It is important to focus on the things that can help us in that direction, and oil and gas extraction is one of those steps, because we cannot yet rely solely on, for example, wind energy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I believe that the current situation is a turning point in the UK’s position regarding energy. The Russian invasion of Ukraine created the need for energy self-sufficiency—not only in the UK, but also in the EU. The environmental impacts of oil and gas extraction in the North Sea are extremely concerning, but not taking action could be far more damaging in the future due to Russia’s incursions into British waters and territories, which are constantly taking place and are a matter of national security.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I believe that the government should reduce spending on development aid for several reasons. It has been shown that the effect of the aid is not significant compared to the amount of support given. A better solution might be to establish profitable businesses instead. When the economy in the UK does not provide better conditions for pensioners in the UK, there is no justification for spending large amounts on development aid. If the economy in the UK improves significantly, a reduction would be unnecessary.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text:
I believe that the money spent on development aid could be used here at home for vulnerable citizens such as the elderly, people with disabilities, and those with mental illnesses.  
Support is also needed for young people with disabilities who are just starting out in life and need someone to catch them and help them move forward, perhaps into a flex job, and to be seen as a resource instead of a burden, just like the elderly. We cannot justify treating especially young people this way, regardless of the challenges it may bring.  
Let the elderly work in some kind of dignified arrangement for as long as they are able.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I believe that we should reduce spending on development aid, as I think we have a greater need to use the money within the UK’s borders. I strongly feel that psychiatry and elderly care are in significant need of financial improvement, and I believe that the money we spend on development aid could be used in the sectors that benefit psychiatry and elderly care. We have a responsibility to our own citizens, and when the waiting time in psychiatry is as long as it is, and when a term like “the burden of the elderly” is even used, I think the money for development aid should go to a different fund.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I believe the government should reduce development aid because our elderly and children in the UK are suffering. It is the elderly citizens who have helped build this country, and they are the ones who are worst off. Likewise, it is our children, who will continue to live in the UK, who are struggling the most. Help our own people in the UK before we help others.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I believe the state should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea so that we become self-sufficient, just as they have done in Norway, and become independent of oil from the Middle East and gas from Russia, since we cannot expect foreign supplies to be stable, and they are too expensive. By being self-sufficient, the income stays in the country.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I can certainly understand that, right here and now, a new tax may seem annoying, as it will limit your and my opportunities for private consumption. But I would ask you to try to think a little further into the future. My children are adults, and I have a couple of wonderful grandchildren. If you and I don’t do something now, those two, when they grow older, will end up paying significantly more than we do, if they are to survive on this planet. They might even be forced to take up arms against other people because there isn’t enough space or resources for everyone!
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I can see advantages in the government introducing a CO2 tax on the groceries and energy sources that pollute the most, as this would make it more beneficial to make healthy choices, since they would also be the cheapest. This would benefit all of us, as we would then take better care of our planet. In addition to having a positive impact on our environment, I also believe it would have a positive effect on our health, including, for example, our respiratory system, since we would not be exposed to as much car exhaust and so on, as goods would not have to be transported as far, making it more advantageous to buy locally.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I care a lot about solar and wind energy, but if there isn’t enough of these energies, I definitely think we should promote oil and gas so that we can be self-sufficient here in the UK. I’m somewhat opposed to us having to import these energies from other countries if it’s possible to extract them ourselves. So yes, go ahead and do that.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I definitely think that groceries and energy, which pollute the most, should be subject to a CO2 tax. It is important that, as citizens, we are aware that the choices we make in our consumption are as non-polluting as possible. It is for the good of us all that this is the case. One should not act selfishly with one's choices, but be in solidarity with one's fellow citizens in striving for the least possible pollution. As a supplement to my position on pollution, I would also like to advocate that air travel be minimized to the absolute necessary and preferably burdened with a large tax.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I definitely think this is something that should be done. We have one planet, and we must take care of it and do everything we can. If we want to make sure that our children and their children, and so on and so on, have just as good a planet as the rest of us, then we will all have to do everything we can, even if it might mean an extra tax for some people.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I do not believe it is justifiable for the government to promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea. It is important that we as a country ensure energy independence, but not at the expense of our environment. The consequences of extracting oil and gas can be catastrophic for our nature; that is precisely why we previously agreed to stop it. Our focus going forward should be on green energy, and if we invest wisely in green solutions, we can still ensure energy independence without risking significant environmental damage.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I do not believe that a tax on food can help reduce CO2 emissions. If that were the case, we would have heard that inflation a few years ago had helped reduce consumption and thereby reduce CO2 emissions. More taxes on food will simply be yet another administrative burden, both for stores and for the agency that has to administer the tax.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I do not believe that the British government should introduce a CO2 tax on the groceries and energy that pollute the most in order to reduce CO2 emissions. I do not think this is beneficial for the average Brit's financial situation. Recently, we have seen a significant increase in the prices of groceries, which is a major economic problem for many citizens.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I do not believe that the government should introduce a CO2 tax on groceries and energy. This is because we are already living in a time where things are only getting more expensive, and by introducing such a tax, there would be more of the things we consider everyday/normal items to buy that fewer and fewer people would actually be able to afford. This would contribute to increasing the gap between rich and poor, which is already growing in society.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I do not believe that the government should promote further oil and gas extraction in the North Sea, because it goes against both climate ambitions, responsible resource management, and the necessary green transition. We are in the midst of a global climate crisis, and the science is clear. In order to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees, as set out in the Paris Agreement, the majority of the world’s known fossil reserves must remain in the ground. It would therefore be irresponsible for the UK to continue or promote extraction. Furthermore, it sends a poor signal to the rest of the world.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I do not think it is fair that consumers or producers should pay more than they already do. That is absolutely not what we need in today’s the UK with rising food prices and increased living costs. the UK cannot take the lead in being climate neutral. That should be the responsibility of large countries such as the USA and China. I think the argument that we should be role models for all other countries is silly, because no one notices what we do anyway. We are just ruining our own economy.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I do not think that more immigrants should be allowed into the country. Many of those we already have are deeply criminal, and we spend both money and resources on them. Many of those who have been expelled are not actually expelled, and the government protects them. It costs society so much. The police do not have time for the tasks they should be handling because they are busy patrolling and keeping an eye on drug dealing, etc. Our elderly and old people cannot get the care they are entitled to. They have served our country for so many years, and yet immigrants are prioritized. They drain the state treasury as much as they can.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I do not think the government should reduce spending on development aid, because we have a moral obligation to help people in need – and because, in this way, we can reduce the number of citizens from poor countries in the South who seek a tolerable life in the North. We should use development aid to create lasting solutions regarding jobs, supplies, and educational opportunities in the countries that need it. If we reduce it, we will end up only offering emergency aid and thus have to spend many more resources keeping migrants out at the borders.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I don't know if I can do that, but it would be common sense to become independent of others.  Granted, I am an older person, but I am sensible, which many others are not. I think about the future and our descendants. Maybe we should look at other expenses in relation to how the entire British administration is structured, how much money is wasted on the establishment of various committees that don't make any progress at all.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I don't think it's acceptable for us not to save on CO2, but imposing higher taxes on groceries is a very bad idea. We all need essential groceries for a reasonably healthy diet, which is already quite monotonous due to food prices. We need groceries for our personal hygiene as well, and that has also become much more expensive now. Since my husband and I are state pensioners and have no other income, we already have to scrimp and save. We pay our taxes gladly and have done so all our lives, and we have raised our four children to be hardworking with good habits.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I don't think the government should accept more asylum seekers fleeing from war and persecution, because in the UK we are already under pressure in our society and economy. I believe we should focus more on what we already have and the resources we have available in society. If the situation were reversed and the UK was at war, we wouldn't receive help from those countries either, as they don't have the means to help us.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I don't think the government should accept more asylum seekers fleeing from war or persecution, as over time there will be fewer and fewer British values in the country. It weakens the country's values and the morale of the people. Furthermore, their way of life, beliefs, and traditions are not worth preserving in the UK.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I don't think the government should introduce a CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most in order to reduce emissions. There are other ways we can reduce CO2 emissions, as we can use nature to help us. Firstly, we can make an effort to stop the felling of our millennia-old rainforests, which unfortunately are now being cut down on a large scale in many countries. We can eat less meat and more vegetables. We can plant more forests ourselves, so we help nature along and reduce CO2 emissions. We can use more solar energy, etc., and phase out gas.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I don't think the government should put taxes on ordinary everyday goods and energy, since it's already expensive enough to live as it is. Even the products that don't emit much CO2 are still fucking expensive, and people can barely make their budgets work. If we agreed that all the products that don't emit much CO2 became MUCH cheaper instead, then it would probably be easier to accept a tax on things that pollute.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I feel that too much of the responsibility for CO2 emissions and environmental pollution falls on the individual, and it becomes too confusing to navigate – the average person has no idea about their own responsibility and what it does to the environment and CO2. If we want real changes to happen, it has to come from the top through legislation and regulation.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think a CO2 tax should be introduced on all goods imported by air, since we emit a lot of CO2, but the tax should also be removed from local goods produced in the UK. What pollutes more? An airplane with avocados, or a cow in the barn? Prices have become completely distorted in the stores.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think a CO2 tax should be introduced on groceries and energy that pollute the most, in order to reduce emissions. I think so because we have an overconsumption of groceries and energy, and people buy without thinking, and many have no opinion about it. So if a tax is introduced, the consumption of the most polluting products will decrease, and CO2 emissions will also decrease, as people will opt out of these products.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think it is a really good idea to have a tax, because it can be difficult for the average citizen to do something for the climate. In this way, people are forced to make an effort and perhaps choose a better alternative. It will promote our efforts and at the same time make them more streamlined. It will help everyone to contribute further.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think it is important that we take precautions regarding the climate crises that have arisen. In this context, we should introduce taxes on the groceries that pollute the most, as we should minimize our CO2 emissions. This will create greater focus on the groceries that pollute the most. In this way, we can change the production of these goods and thereby create a more climate-friendly production. By introducing this, we can together create a more climate-friendly planet that can last for many years.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think it is necessary to do something. We can't just continue down the same path year after year. If we are to change anything, it has to be managed by the government, for example with taxes on polluting goods and perhaps reduced VAT on goods that do not pollute. I don't believe in relying solely on voluntary action. Unfortunately...
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think it is very important that we help everyone who has to flee from war and other unrest in the world. What do you think—if we were in the same situation and had to flee, wouldn’t it be nice if there were places in the world where we could get asylum and help? Think of the poor children in Gaza who cannot get help because the UK does not want to bring them here, since we help in another way. I think it would be a great help for them to receive help here.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I think our British state should reduce our payments to development aid, since we also need to help our own people, such as those who are ill, people on welfare, and those with mental illnesses who need a lot of help. Children in care should receive much more attention regarding how they are doing and experiencing things. Our homeless, who are struggling with addiction and living on the streets, and our poor families who have very little to live on. the UK needs to wake up and help our own people who need help here in the UK. We are doing far too little to help our own vulnerable citizens.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think that criminals from other countries should be sent back to their home countries, regardless of the consequences this may have for the individuals concerned.   We already have citizens who cannot behave, and we also need to take into account immigrants and asylum seekers.  It is better to use the funds to improve conditions for the elderly and sick instead of continually sending money out of the country.  Unfortunately, it apparently has not had the desired effect on improving developing countries.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text:
I think that groceries have already increased a lot in price, and if specific items are to become even more expensive, it will mean that people who don’t earn much won’t be able to afford those products.  
If people want the products, even though a tax has been added, they will probably find the money for them. Just look at cigarettes: people still smoke, even though they are quite expensive.  
Many people are very aware of their CO2 footprint and are already thinking about how they can reduce it and help the environment that way.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think the British government generally spends too much money on helping outside the UK, for example large sums to help in connection with war. Many people who come to the UK do not really have a need, and it is far too easy to ask for asylum and residence permits. My perception is that it is too easy, and that is the reputation we have abroad: Travel to the UK, it’s easy. The government should spend more help on improving welfare in British society – children and young people. Lead by example without high salaries for themselves and the good pension scheme.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I think the government should accept more asylum seekers who are fleeing war or persecution, as it is our duty to help the vulnerable. And everyone remembers World War II and the persecution of the Jews. I don't think we are interested in repeating that. And we should treat others as we would like to be treated ourselves. And doesn't everyone want to be helped if we are persecuted?
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I think the government should accept more asylum seekers who are fleeing war or persecution, as they need help. They are in a situation they cannot get out of, and the government should help them in the best possible way. This does not mean that everyone should be allowed to enter the country, but it should be people who are genuinely fleeing from war or persecution.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I think the government should accept more asylum seekers who are fleeing war or persecution, because the UK is a country that has the resources to receive them and give them a life where they can create value and be a productive part of society. There are other countries that do not have these resources, which are forced to take them in instead, because they do not, in the same way as the UK and other wealthy countries, have the option to send them away, and/or because this is where they end up after being rejected elsewhere. This is a problem both for the country they end up in and for the person themselves.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I think the government should focus more on imposing taxes on CO2-emitting activities for companies rather than for private individuals. This is considering how little influence private individuals actually have on climate change compared to large companies. It seems very symbolic and without much effect.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think the government should introduce a CO2 tax because it would make harmful products more expensive and motivate consumers and producers to switch to more sustainable alternatives. Such a tax would also send a clear signal that, as a society, we prioritize the environment and take responsibility for the long-term consequences of our consumption. If the price of the most polluting goods reflects their real environmental costs, it will become easier, more natural, and more normal for people to make choices that benefit the climate as much as possible. In this way, we can protect nature and improve sustainability.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think the government should introduce a CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most, in order to reduce emissions. A tax will increase the price of the product and will therefore likely encourage people to seek less polluting solutions. A tax will thus minimize the sale of polluting goods and/or resources and thereby reduce emissions.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think the government should introduce a CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most, in order to reduce emissions. As the climate is becoming more and more polluted, it is important to focus on the issue. We need to think more about the climate, and we can do that by buying more sustainable products. If grocery and energy prices rise so that the products which pollute the most become more expensive to produce, it will mean that consumers will turn to alternatives that are more sustainable. This will promote the process and help the climate.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think the government should introduce a CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most. I believe this because I think we need to take much better care of our children's future, and they depend on us not polluting and destroying the planet they will inherit. All research shows that taxes and rising prices make people opt out of certain products; for example, many have stopped buying ground beef, which has become much more expensive. This is good for the climate, as beef is one of the major CO2 offenders. If we are to have a planet to pass on to our children, we therefore need a “ground beef law.”
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I think the government should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence, so that we become more self-sufficient and therefore do not have to buy energy from countries with which we do not share views on humanity, respect for the international community, and for the integrity and borders of all countries.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I think the government should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence. And I think so because then it could become cheaper to use your car and fill up. It is simply far too expensive as it is right now. And that’s why I think something active should be done about it.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I think the government should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence. It is the only correct thing to do, because we can prove that we are among the best at extracting combustion energies from our underground resources. Furthermore, it helps provide a bit more financial leeway in the mess that the government has brought the UK into.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I think the government should reduce spending on development aid because the money could be used to ensure better elderly care in our country. Savings are always made in the area of elderly care, but now we need to ensure a better quality of life for our elderly. There should be more sorting of which countries need some support and which countries can be excluded. There should be better oversight of how the aid is used in the countries we support.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think the government should reduce spending on development aid because: Although the UK can be considered a developed country with a fairly high standard of living, there are many Brits who are poor. I don't think we should give money away and let families with children go hungry. Even though there are some countries in Africa that are worse off, I don't think it should be our responsibility.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think the government should reduce spending on development aid, because we have provided aid for at least my entire lifetime (I am 68 years old). The African inhabitants don’t stop having many children, and our aid almost makes them even more fertile, even into old age. Contraception is the solution, but their religion stands in the way of that. Therefore, we should throw in the towel.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think the prices of everything are too high. Since I am on early retirement, I can't get a driver's license, so it doesn't affect me. I only have a bicycle. I don't know what I can do about any of it; I'm just trying to enjoy my life after I got a late brain injury. I also think it should be more advantageous to drive an electric car than one that runs on fuel.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think there are plenty of poor people here at home who could use some help. It can't be right that children and pensioners are starving and can't make ends meet. I'm almost 70 years old, and since I was a child, the "poor" children have been starving in Africa. It's easy not to do anything about it when they get money coming in every month. Just think how many people here at home could have food on the table every day.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think they should promote oil and gas extraction so that we can be self-sufficient and not be so affected by what happens around us. This will be very significant for our country, so it can 'stand on its own two feet.' Plus, if we really get going, there might also be a surplus to sell to other countries.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I think we should cut back a bit on the aid, because a lot of the money we provide ends up in the wrong pockets, and much of it is also spent on administration. I also think that we have a lot of people in the UK who need help. There are many vulnerable people who are struggling to make ends meet, and the same goes for many pensioners, so that's why we should give less.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think we should cut back on development aid, as the UK itself needs more resources at the moment. Our healthcare system is struggling, and both children and the elderly are being neglected every day. In addition, we have many people with mental illnesses who also lack funding. We need to think of ourselves first and foremost. Once we have things under control here, we will be in a much better position to help others.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think we should help where we can, and of course it shouldn’t just be anyone. You can’t expect people to live in such a way that they have neither food, clothing, nor aids. We should try to put ourselves in their place; how would we feel if it were us? If we can help in any way, we should, but of course they must be integrated into how we live and do things here in the UK.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I think we should reduce spending on development aid, as it has already cost the UK a lot of money. I believe that this money could be used in more important areas instead, as I think the most important thing is for Brits to have better quality welfare. I think the healthcare sector needs to be improved significantly, more resources should go to kindergartens and other public authorities, and our elderly should have better opportunities.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I think we should stop, as there are other things in the world that are more important to spend money on. It could be anything from our somewhat deteriorating defense or our health losses in the form of nurses who don’t have the best working conditions—at least as I hear it. Furthermore, I just think some strange decisions are made in politics from time to time.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I understand and respect that you have a different opinion, but if I may explain why I think this is actually a good idea, I hope we can agree that this would be the best for our the UK. I see this as good for the UK, as we will become less dependent on our friends and even our enemies. The more self-sufficient we can be in terms of energy, the less we have to worry about losing resources for energy. This will create security among all of us Brits. Imagine that we are independent of others when it comes to having a stable energy resource.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: I understand that it seems unfair that we have to pay even more for our consumption when prices are already so high. But what I think is worth remembering in this debate is that if we don’t reduce our CO2 emissions now, we will end up having to pay even more in the future when we have to protect ourselves against, for example, flooding. Studies show that our consumption plays a huge role in global warming, and we can save ourselves large bills in just five to ten years by reducing CO2 emissions now. But it also has to be now—for ourselves and for our children.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I understand the concern about whether we have the resources to take in more refugees. But instead of seeing it as a burden, we should see it as an opportunity to strengthen our society. By increasing the number of approved asylum seekers who gain access to the labor market, we get motivated people who want to contribute and rebuild their lives. If we can help them become self-sufficient quickly, we minimize the long-term expenses and maximize the positive contributions to society.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: If I were to persuade someone who does not agree with me that the government should accept more asylum seekers who are fleeing from war and/or persecution, I would try to say to the person: try to put yourself in their place. They are traumatized, have no money or food – and need food and shelter and probably, most of all, need to get away from the war they have experienced in their home country or the persecution they have faced. They need to get to a place where there is no war – where they can feel safe, and where there is no bombing, shooting, or the like.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: If nothing is done about our CO2 emissions, and the green transition in general does not become more widespread, the world will end up not being a livable place. Maybe it won’t be the case for our generation, but many generations to come will feel a difference if we don’t do something now.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: If nothing is done now, it may not affect us, but our children and grandchildren. Companies should take responsibility to ensure that their surplus goods are used responsibly—possibly for reuse and not thrown away or burned. If they are unwilling to do this, a CO2 tax should be introduced for everything they throw away.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: If the government can ensure that the money goes to the purposes they have designated, and does not end up in the pockets of those in power or other individuals due to corruption in the country in question, the aid can be given. Furthermore, there must be oversight of the aid organization delivering the assistance, so that a large part of it does not merely support the organization itself, but that the funds actually reach the people for whom they were intended.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: If the government promotes oil and gas extraction in the North Sea, it will have many advantages for energy independence. the UK will become less dependent on other countries and imported energy sources, which can be a good idea in times when there may be political instability or geopolitical conflicts. Therefore, we can strategically protect ourselves against international crises and price fluctuations. Domestic production also means that there is a better opportunity to influence price and supply nationally, instead of being dependent on and priced by an international market where many political and economic factors come into play.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: If we assume that CO2 emissions are a significant factor in the accelerating global warming, it is important that everyone – both at the corporate level and in the private sphere – participates in reducing these emissions. If one can significantly reduce emissions by opting out of goods and services with the largest CO2 footprint, it seems obvious that this is one of the paths we must take.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: If we assume that both the government and society as a whole actually believe in the principle that "the polluter pays," then it must be obvious that a CO2 tax should be imposed on all goods. From there, it must be the producers' responsibility to ensure that their goods are produced as neutrally as possible, because the price increase that will naturally follow will make consumers extremely critical when they are in the supermarket.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: If we can promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence, we should investigate whether we can make it succeed. We would have our own oil and gas and not be dependent on other countries. It would definitely be a huge advantage to promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
If we don't support the poor countries, there will be more refugees, because poverty creates more refugees. The rich countries need to provide more support.
Poverty creates more refugees, so we need to support the poor countries, otherwise people won't want to live there and will do anything to escape.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: If we don’t do something about CO2 emissions, our grandchildren will suffer. They won’t have the same opportunities as us. So if you want to help the people of the future, give your support to future CO2 taxes, which can help reduce CO2 emissions. The tax will also force everyone to help.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: If you don't want large-scale immigration, you need to give those who flee their country a good reason to stay. If you live in a country where it isn't possible to live decently, it's obvious that you would move to one of the rich countries in the world. For example, if the Sahara could become fertile just with the help of machines that capture the moisture in the air, people would have the opportunity to support themselves. Brits would probably prefer to live in the UK and have a good life in their own country, wouldn't they? And what about, for example, if part of the Sahara were covered with solar panels? Or maybe wind turbines...
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Imagine if we spent all the money we send out of the country on: The elderly – so they could have a bath more than once a week, get their homes vacuumed, and experience that there was time to be present with them. Higher salaries for public employees – maybe more people would choose this as a workplace. More military equipment – so we wouldn’t be so dependent on the USA. VAT reduction – so food wouldn’t be so expensive, and everyone would have the opportunity to get proper meals.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: In 1985 there was a famine in Ethiopia. Live Aid and charity songs were organized to counteract the famine (emergency aid was flown in). This was followed by 35 years of civil war in Ethiopia itself. That is, the kids who were saved from starving to death back then have since done everything they could to kill each other. So it was a waste of money and effort.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: In general, I am opposed to imposing additional forms of taxes and duties, which means that families who are already struggling financially are burdened with further expenses. I would not mind higher tax payments for those who can afford it. But that requires a complete change to our tax system. Why is this my argument, as stated in the introduction??? Because, among other things, I am an unpaid volunteer debt counselor in KFUM's social department "Back on Your Feet," where we see many socially vulnerable people who are already struggling with rising prices—not just for food, but also for electricity, water, and heating!
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: In light of the increasing inequality, a tax should be introduced on CO2-intensive everyday goods that can be substituted or are not basic necessities. That is, products where there would be an economic advantage in using other products, such as types of meat, and products whose production is resource-intensive. All else being equal, this would result in a minimal overall welfare loss.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: In my opinion, the environment and climate change are the most serious problems facing humanity. Therefore, it is essential to use all means to limit CO2 emissions. A CO2 tax is an initiative that would have a significant beneficial impact in this regard. A CO2 tax cannot stand alone in the critical situation the planet is in.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: In terms of food, we have plenty of good ingredients on British soil—ingredients that we can make much greater use of than we currently do. We have good alternatives to many imported ingredients—so when it is possible to grow British alternatives, I see it as natural that we use them. I see a clear need for us to learn to use both ourselves and nature more sustainably—to learn that things take time, that ingredients are available when they are in season, and that energy sources should not be depleted. The more we respect and connect with nature, the more we will be able to find balance as human beings.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: In the UK, integration is going quite well because we have always been able to keep up with integrating the refugees we have received. If we had received many more, like in Sweden, we would now have had "Swedish conditions," so I don't think we should increase the number of especially Muslim refugees, but I am fine with people from Ukraine.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: In the UK, we accept many asylum seekers who do not want to adapt to the British society and be part of the British norm or do not want to fit in. This creates a number of problems with equality in the UK and can cause a lot of issues regarding how we Brits see the UK and what the UK really is and stands for.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: In the UK, we constantly hear that there is a lack of money for elderly care, children, and the healthcare system. Nevertheless, we spend far too much money on asylum seekers. Many of the asylum seekers admitted to the UK do not contribute to the country and live on welfare benefits. By reducing the number of asylum seekers we approve, we will have more money for our citizens.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: In the current global situation, it is important to be self-sufficient. The countries are, together, far too dependent on each other—a tiny conflict can end fatally. Therefore, in the long run, it is more important to go your own way instead of relying on others. This could also be of great benefit going forward.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: In the last 50 years or more, we have faithfully sent money after one famine disaster after another. Already when I was a little boy, we were shown pictures of hungry African children. We diligently collected money for them at school, in the expectation that they would get food and a roof over their heads. What actually happened? Well, plenty of money was sent down there, but it primarily enriched those in power and various NGOs. Only a fraction went to the hungry children... Today we see the same pictures and are once again told that we need to give more support. No, the only thing that helps is a reduction in population growth.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Industries that do not comply with pollution control laws should be severely punished, and their operating permits should be revoked. Afterwards, the British population should work together to avoid such companies that do not take the environment into account. Reducing emissions into the atmosphere will help protect the ecosystem and promote a healthy lifestyle and the production of healthy food at home.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Introducing a tax on groceries and energy is completely the wrong way to go. First of all, we already have enough taxes to keep track of. A new tax would require new employees to monitor whether it is being paid correctly, as well as new campaigns and information about the tax. The path we should take is to stop with all these taxes and use a single tax, such as VAT.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It affects us who are on welfare. We can't afford anything since the new rules came in. We should have more to get by on. They should replace those who are able to work. There are some who can't work; they get more in welfare, so let those who are sick be left alone. There are many who pretend to be sick; they just get sick pay. It's unfair to those on welfare.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It cannot be the intention for the government to introduce a tax on everyday goods. The place where action should be taken regarding the CO2 tax must be with those who produce the goods. It should be up to others to assess where something can be done. Think about all the other things that emit CO2. If we in the UK are to be able to supply pigs, etc., CO2 will be emitted. We are and must continue to be British, and we must have farmers to live by.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It is always important to be able to stand on your own two feet, and that is why it is important for a country to be independent in every way, including when it comes to energy. Therefore, the UK should promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence. All the uncertainty in the world means that right now it is most important for the UK to think of itself and promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure independence. the UK is a good and wise country, and that is why we must stand firm and secure our independence now.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is an economic advantage for the British state and provides independence from supplies from other states. Natural gas can, for example, be mixed with biogas, thereby achieving a reduced emission of CO2. In addition, natural gas is a necessary basic material for the production of, for example, certain types of fertilizer. Oil can, after being refined into, for example, fuel, be mixed with bioethanol, which results in reduced CO2 emissions.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is basically very simple. Our beautiful world can no longer handle the pressure. We may be developing and getting smarter every day, but are we really? In fact, we are getting dumber every day, and if we don’t start tightening up seriously right now, the world we know will become very gray and boring and perhaps, ultimately, uninhabitable. I think that if you want to have children, you should show and teach them this. And wouldn’t it just be great if we all started using our heads, then we could all live in harmony, etc. #peoplecouldn’tcareless #climatechangecoldworld
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It is common human behavior to help those in need. If we absolutely have to bomb around the world, then we certainly also need to be aware that there are victims who need help afterwards. We are a wealthy society, so of course we can afford it, since we clearly can afford to buy bombs.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: It is completely wrong to believe that we will become energy independent by tapping our planet for oil and gas. Our production and supply sites will be very vulnerable to the possibility of hostile powers destroying them. Sun and wind, after all, are not something that can be removed by the Russians or others who wish to harm us. Furthermore, the use of gas and oil is still not free from pollution.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.
