Text: It is foolish that we import gas and oil in Europe when we can still find some in the North Sea and export it to the rest of Europe. That would help stop all imports in Europe from Russia; it should be logical. In this way, we can support Ukraine even better, and we get more money in the state treasury, which can be used for welfare improvements.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important not to be dependent on other countries. Standing alone is preferable on all levels. It is also important for the development of the UK as a country that can and wants to stand alone, that we are energy independent, so that in the future we are also in a stronger position if we have to enter into negotiations with other countries about other matters.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that development is supported in places other than just the Western world, so that third world countries also make progress and can better support their own development. At the same time, this will help reduce the number of economic refugees to the Western world and thus address another challenge for the Western world.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: It is important that in these times we try to make ourselves as independent as possible from Russia and other states when it comes to gas and oil, as a supplement to wind and solar power, so that we can have a stable energy supply around the clock. If the sun isn’t shining and the wind isn’t blowing, we need a backup. That we might eventually find another backup is a completely different matter.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that people in need are helped, especially those in the greatest need, such as women and children who are traumatized by war and have had prolonged insecure stays in refugee camps. These are not respected by warring nations, who rape, mutilate, and starve women and children. If you see us as a humanitarian nation that supports the UN and human rights, we should help where the need is greatest, currently especially pronounced in Gaza and partly in Ukraine.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: It is important that we are self-sufficient with oil and gas, so it is important that we support this. At the same time as oil and gas extraction, we should of course also have offshore wind turbines, so that the UK becomes completely independent of supply from other countries. There is no reason to buy from other countries if we can supply ourselves, and it may even become cheaper for the consumer when there aren’t too many intermediaries involved.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that we can become energy independent, so that we can manage on our own and are not dependent on other countries, especially if a crisis should occur. By promoting oil and gas extraction, it will increase the possibilities of being independent of energy from other countries. Therefore, this is a really good idea for us.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that we can supply ourselves as a country, so that in the event of war, we are not dependent on others. We need to be able to keep society running, even if other countries try to dictate to us and intimidate us by cutting off, for example, gas or oil supplies. In this way, we will also be able to maintain a certain standard of living.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that we share our abundance with our fellow human beings, because in our private daily lives we live in abundance. Our consumption of food, heating, and shelter far exceeds what is necessary for survival. Moreover, the aforementioned items make up a relatively small part of our total private consumption. An increase in the number of refugees costs money initially, for socialization and establishment, but in the long run we need more labor, so by helping refugees we kill two birds with one stone. The most important thing is compassion, also in the broadest sense.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: It is important to have cheap and environmentally friendly food products, which is why it should be cheaper to buy vegetables, rye bread, and similar items. Better to have higher taxes on candy and cakes. It is important that, in everyday life, there is enough money for good, inexpensive foods that are healthy, especially for pensioners and children. After all, it is not essential to have candy and meat every day. On the other hand, basic foods should be affordable.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It is important to look at which countries receive development aid. It is better to consider how we can help make the countries that receive money today more self-sufficient. One should not support countries that may be at war, but rather wait until there is enough peace for the effort to have a lasting effect. It is also important to provide support in the country itself and not bring people to the UK who will not be able to adapt to our traditions in the country.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: It is more important for the UK to get control of the healthcare system, psychiatry, etc., than to help abroad. We are the ones who pay British taxes and VAT, and we should also benefit from it ourselves. I have nothing against people abroad, but it doesn’t make sense to support others before we have our own affairs and challenges in order.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: It is much more important to invest in renewable energy solutions than to increase oil and gas extraction in the North Sea – for the sake of the escalating climate changes we are witnessing in the year 2025, with catastrophic long-term costs for humanity. Frightening temperature increases – which intensify drought and lead to numerous forest fires – are greatly damaging the planet’s ecological conditions. Rising floods are affecting many places around the world, resulting in incalculable human losses.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is one of the most insane things not to use the oil and gas resources we have in our own subsoil, but instead import them; it is completely and utterly absurd. Then you might as well say that it’s perfectly fine to use resources from another country, thereby polluting with more CO2 than necessary.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is pointless for the UK to shut down oil and gas production as long as there is a need for oil and gas in the UK, and furthermore imports oil and gas from distant countries with long, expensive, and CO2-intensive transport. In the same context, the oil and gas industry could be forced to use the least environmentally damaging tools, including vehicles, cleaning agents, and electricity.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is the government's responsibility to promote clean energy. Taxes and fines should be imposed on industries that pollute the environment. This will lead to healthier lives for people in the UK. People should be educated to support industries that prioritize sustainability and reject goods and services from companies that do not meet this requirement.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It is very important to be self-sufficient with oil and gas so that we do not have to depend on other countries, especially Russia. Since no one knows what the future holds, it is important to be able to manage on our own. We need to start extraction in the North Sea ourselves. We need the energy in our country, as everyone needs it.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is very necessary to use non-fossil energy sources in the future so that we reduce CO2 emissions. All experts assess that the climate is deteriorating, which has already happened in many places around the globe. This leads to people fleeing from the hardest-hit areas, which intensifies the refugee crisis. At present, there are already areas that have either turned into desert or are flooded, making them uninhabitable.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is, after all, the most logical—that those who consume the groceries and the energy that pollute the most should also be the ones who pay for it. In this way, the burden of payment falls in the right place, and the actual consumers can and must themselves decide whether they want to change their consumption or pay for it.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It makes no sense to introduce a CO2 tax that only affects British companies. The UK accounts for a small percentage of the world’s CO2, so unless other countries join in, it simply won’t work. Instead, it will just become expensive for British companies, and the price of goods will rise. Then people will start importing cheaper goods from abroad, and the result will be exactly the opposite, since the transport here must also be included in the climate accounts.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text:
It must be the polluter who pays; in this case, the consumer who causes a larger CO2 emission.  
It is about shifting consumption towards goods that pollute less with CO2, but also ensuring that food prices in general do not rise. Alternatively, one could make the least polluting goods cheaper, for example by reducing the VAT on fruit and vegetables.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It will make it more expensive for the average citizen to survive in a world with already rising prices and inflation that does not stop. It will only make it more costly and more difficult to use the current resources, which are already expensive and cannot be saved on in this economy. Therefore, it makes no sense to introduce a CO2 tax on, among other things, groceries and energy, which pollute the most, in order to reduce emissions. It will also become more expensive to travel and get around during the summer holidays, when half of the UK is on vacation and wants to enjoy their time abroad. These are some of the arguments.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It's already expensive enough to live. Introducing taxes might help a little, but there will still be people who buy the products. However, they are tired of it. It would be better to take action purely in terms of the climate, instead of limiting the joy of ordinary citizens and making everyday life more miserable than it already can be.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It’s a never-ending cycle, because they have more children, and these will live a miserable life. One should rather assist with how they can best manage, for example by having fewer children, hygiene courses, cultivation and sale of crops, etc. Furthermore, one cannot be sure that the emergency aid reaches the right people in need.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: It’s all about the distance and the culture in the EU compared to the Middle East/USA. The distance must be minimal, and the workers must be ensured a wage that makes sense. This can only be done in one way, and there are several articles about it from the EU and other member states. EU first! The Middle East does not take biodiversity into account, and the same goes for the USA, which drills for oil in Alaska’s nature reserves.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Let industries that do not comply with pollution laws pay a high fine. The public should also do their part by boycotting industries that pollute the air. Their license can be revoked until they comply with these laws. These charges should be imposed on industries. Those who comply with these laws should receive the surplus from these taxes to further develop their industries.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Many people with a culture that differs significantly from the British one create division and problems. Values that do not align with those that are predominant undermine the cohesion of a country. The expenses for asylum seekers residing in the UK are very high, and many more people can be helped for less money in the local areas.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: Most of the development funds we send to developing countries end up in the wrong pockets, end up in larger cities, and rarely help where they could benefit a poor rural population. An example could be China, to which we send development aid! Seriously. In addition, we often send aid to places where there is no one to maintain and take over the projects. A water purification plant is great, but if there isn’t a sales apparatus that ensures there are locals who have an interest in building expertise in it and maintaining it, it doesn’t make sense.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Most people who flee from war come from Muslim countries. It would be better if they stayed in a Muslim country, where they share the same culture. If we first bring them to the UK, they won’t go back again, and they have difficulty adapting to the British culture. I think the help should be given in the local area. The money also goes further there.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: My opinion is that a CO2 tax should not be introduced on the goods that pollute the most, because it is the consumer who ends up paying. People on transfer incomes cannot have this expense covered, as they cannot ask for a pay raise and thus cover the additional cost.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: No matter how many wind turbines we set up and how many solar panels are installed, no one in this world can guarantee that the sun will always shine and that it will always be windy. Therefore, we are 100% dependent on a backup plan, and oil/gas/biogas/straw/wood chips are the only alternatives until we get control of a hydrogen production that can deliver the required amounts (and then solar and wind turbines become redundant), or we get small fusion reactors near the cities that can balance the need for extra electricity (and thus make wind and solar redundant again).
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: North Sea oil and gas are the UK’s own energy resources, and increased production can reduce dependence on imported energy. For example, domestic production in winter, when energy demand peaks, can provide a stable supply, which could potentially lead to fewer conflicts between suppliers and fewer transport disruptions. This gives the UK the opportunity to allocate electricity for heating in homes and production in businesses more independently.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Of course, we need to take care of nature and not exploit it, because we can live on small incomes so that others can take advantage of our resources. We need to protect our nature. If we are to extract, there also need to be ships to transport goods from the seabed, so it’s not as green as people want it to be. So let it be, so that other countries can benefit and pollute more.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Oil is already known as a major environmental burden, so by promoting oil and gas extraction we will accelerate the pollution that is already underway. According to experts, developments are heading in a bad direction, and if we do not stop the use of gas and oil, it will have environmental consequences that our children and grandchildren will have to deal with. We owe it to the future to make choices that promote as clean a climate as possible, and we do not do that by extracting gas and oil.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Okay, I know we disagree, but we won’t in 10 years, when the whole world slows down. More and more CO2 is being emitted, and if we don’t pay the taxes, we won’t have the means to solve this problem, and the world will reach a point where it comes to a standstill. If we all contributed a little, we would secure a better future for our children.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: On a human level, I naturally have great compassion for refugees, but I feel that we have taken in more than our share, and I believe that our own welfare is very much at risk. Things have been cut to the bone when pensioners cannot get the help they need—neither cleaning nor assistance with personal care. It was just reported that there can be 34 residents in a nursing home for one night shift worker. Families with disabled or terminally ill children cannot get help with necessary care, support, or equipment. Prices have risen so much that some people have to choose whether to pay for expensive medicine or buy food. That is rock bottom.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: One of the greatest crises we are facing at the moment is the extreme climate change, and we must do everything we can to promote the green transition. Energy independence is an important parameter. Every single small initiative counts, but promoting oil and gas extraction in the North Sea would make an extreme contribution to energy independence. Furthermore, another extremely important parameter is making ourselves independent of Russian gas — for political, economic, and climate-related reasons.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: One of the most important problems today is climate change, which is largely caused by human consumption. To reduce CO2 emissions, we should change our consumption patterns. The quickest method is to restructure our tax system so that goods and consumption of the most climate-damaging products and services become more expensive, and the less harmful ones become cheaper.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: One should promote oil and gas extraction oneself in order to be more independent and not dependent on fluctuating global prices. Dependence on gas from Russia makes us very vulnerable; you never know what "odd" political measures might come from there. By extracting our own resources, we can also better monitor and protect against possible sabotage, etc.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Other countries are still far behind in establishing green energy. the UK should be self-sufficient in energy and export surplus gas to EU countries. This should also strengthen the state treasury. However, we must at the same time continue to develop green energy from both solar panels and wind turbines, and perhaps also from waves, if it can be done in a way that does not disturb our coastlines.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Overall, we need to reduce CO2 consumption, but I don’t think this should happen by raising already extremely high grocery prices, which puts additional pressure on families who are already struggling—not just financially, but also health-wise, since many vegetables/fruits are imported and would have to be replaced by potentially less healthy alternatives. This puts even more pressure on our healthcare sector, which is already struggling, and thus the extra tax would cost us even more in other areas. Instead, focus on companies and other countries in the EU/world that use much more and can make a difference for the climate through changes.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Perhaps people think that CO2 is the responsibility of the individual. History just shows that you don’t get everyone on board unless there is a carrot or a stick. In this context, it is the government’s responsibility to act as the stick. It is the government, through civil servants and experts, that has the necessary knowledge, and it is knowledge we must trust is correct. If people themselves are unable to take the necessary measures, then it must be the government’s responsibility. We have come so far in burdening the planet that we need to be forced to act.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Refugees are best supported in their local area. All experience shows that it takes many generations to integrate a refugee from a non-democratic country into a secular (non-religious) European country. This leaves the task of integration to ordinary citizens, who did not choose it. Their children are severely harassed at school. The healthcare system and social services become overloaded. Non-integrated refugees will also take all unskilled jobs, for example hospital cleaning, which quickly becomes "brown only." White people needs don't apply.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: Since everything has increased dramatically, the unemployment benefit period is lower than ever before, there are plenty of people on social assistance, we have many families in the UK living at the poverty line, and we lack specialized hospitals and doctors in the local area, I think we have more than enough to spend money on here at home to secure our own welfare—before we secure that of others.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Since we have too many problems integrating the refugees we already have, I believe that more resources should be used to solve these challenges before we can receive more refugees. It is important for our society that we do not receive more refugees than we are able to help; therefore, we should spend money and effort on helping those who are here before we receive more.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: Since world peace is rather uncertain, we need to secure ourselves in every way, so we have different forms of energy we can use if, for example, the electricity supply is interrupted. In that case, we have alternatives that can ensure that hospitals and other important institutions can still function. Everyday life for everyone must be able to continue, regardless of which form of energy is used.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Taxes on the most polluting products can push people to change production methods, reduce transportation, etc., in order to keep prices down and thereby reduce CO2 emissions. Although this may mean higher prices for certain goods or services, it is important that we do everything we can to slow down the greenhouse effect and protect the climate.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Tell me, how are we supposed to get energy when it’s cloudy and there’s no wind... Should we buy expensive energy from abroad to cover our security of supply? What are we supposed to do with all the biogas we produce? And should we continue with wood pellets, which are made from good wood both abroad and here at home, thereby destroying biodiversity?
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: That more is done for the climate in the UK, and that there are better conditions for farmers, and that emissions are reduced, and that consideration is given to the environment, and that we take better care of nature, and that we are aware that it does not become warmer to live in the UK, and that we use less gasoline per year and buy electric cars.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The British economy is healthy, and there is ample room to increase development aid to 1% of GDP. Low-income countries should be supported in their efforts to develop society and increase the population’s prosperity and access to resources and universal rights, as well as the fulfillment of the UN’s global development goals. Development aid should aim to be sector-based and recipient-driven.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The British government should not focus on helping other countries. We, the British people, have enough problems, and we do not owe any country any development aid. Our government should make it a goal to put the country's youth first on their agenda before helping other countries. Infrastructure and economic prosperity should be the goals of our leaders.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The UK currently needs a lot of money itself to strengthen our military and to bring down the prices of food and medicine again. In addition, we have so many homeless people whom we should help before we help other countries. Our country has already given so much money to foreign aid. We cannot keep doing so when our own country is in need. Furthermore, the countries we give foreign aid to are very rich countries — the wealth is just distributed very poorly, but they do not help their own country, which they probably should start doing. Maybe they do not care, and maybe they do care and will help if we stop.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The UK is a country where many unintegrated people from foreign countries already live. Before this problem is solved, we should not let more people into the UK. In case of flooding, you have to turn off the water before you start drying up! It is better to help foreigners in their local area. And the UK already gives above average to foreigners.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The UK is a wealthy country, and there is so much surplus of kindness that we should share it with people who cannot find safety in their own country because of their religion, sexual orientation, skin color, or war. There are so many people who are persecuted, and it is our duty as human beings to help as many as possible in the UK. There are many people who will certainly help those poor people who cannot stay in their homeland.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The UK is a wealthy country, and we can afford to help people in need. We also have a moral obligation to help people who are fleeing from war and persecution. If we don’t help them, then who will? It is important to remember that refugees are people just like us. They have simply been unlucky enough to be born in a country where there is war and persecution. We must treat them with respect and dignity.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The UK is one of the world’s richest countries. What a frightening society we would be if we did not take responsibility for our fellow human beings in less fortunate countries. Chance has given each of us a place in a society where we have opportunities and choices. To reduce spending on development aid would be like reducing ourselves as humanity.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The UK should accept more asylum seekers than we do now. The reason is that it is our duty as a wealthy country to help people fleeing from war and hardship.  Opponents will argue that asylum seekers are expensive, that they cannot be properly integrated, and therefore pose a threat to security and "Britishness." I believe the way we receive asylum seekers—and process their applications for residence—should be changed. If they are quickly integrated into our society, taught English and British culture, and allowed to work while they wait for a residence permit, it will be a benefit for the UK.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The UK should be more self-sufficient with energy and should have continued the development of nuclear power, which has become safer to produce and provides greener energy and a stable supply! We also have a large and well-supplied wind turbine production, which is also a good source of supply for the future need for greener energy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The UK should completely stop giving development aid. We have donated billions to development projects where the money has simply disappeared into the hands of corrupt officials, without any oversight of where the money goes. The UK and the Brits should no longer pay for development aid without getting anything in return. Development aid should be abolished, and real investments should be made with profit in mind. Furthermore, countries that refuse to receive their own citizens who have been convicted of crimes in the UK and have been issued a deportation order should not be able to receive any form of development aid at all.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The UK simply cannot afford to support all these people. Of course, it is really unfortunate for them, but I think we should put ourselves first. We can see it in our healthcare system, where Brits have difficulty getting help/operations within a reasonable time. We can see it in elderly care, where our elderly are neglected and do not get the help they need. We can see it in the justice system, where asylum seekers, etc., are overrepresented. I think we should first make things work for those we already have before we talk about bringing in new ones.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The aid we provide to developing countries is being abused (corruption) or destroyed (civil war), so we never know who actually receives it. In my eyes, it seems like a waste of money. Furthermore, the young people from these countries are fleeing and seeking asylum in Europe, so who will take up the fight against this when only the elderly and weak are left behind? Should we spend money to send them back? So we spend money on development and refugees—it seems unhealthy. So we have to choose where we spend money: refugees, stopping wars, or development—and development seems pointless.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The best argument for introducing a CO2 tax is that the climate footprint keeps increasing. We have to start somewhere, and that is by looking at ourselves. If we take the lead by introducing a CO2 tax here, then other countries might follow suit. I hope the government can see the sense in us being the first to start.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The climate crisis cannot be solved with taxes, only with action. There are too many people on this earth, and since I, like all other hypocrites, do not wish to die, it will have to be someone else. And remember, this is a political thought, which does not reflect that I wish death upon anyone. Political thoughts are hypothetical, but can require action.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The elderly and the schools lack resources; therefore, it is important that we help them in our own country first. There is no evidence that the money we send abroad is used for the right purpose. I think we should spend more money on public schools. The public schools are severely affected. Far too many are included without the necessary resources following. This affects general teaching, and the children have a poor experience of going to school. Those who want to learn cannot get the peace they need. The books are old and worn. The buildings and furniture are in need of an upgrade.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The entire security situation means that we must continue to prevent Russia from gaining the upper hand, as that would allow them to put pressure on Europe, including the UK. At the same time, this will help keep energy prices down, making it cheaper for the populations of the countries to live, so that it does not become a struggle for survival, and so that we help determine control over our own lives.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The expenses simply have to be reduced, because now it’s time for citizens to get something for all the money they’ve paid in taxes and fees. It absolutely cannot be the intention that we should save other countries when our elderly can barely get help. The healthcare system is also lagging behind, so now we’re going to stop being so stupid and giving our money away. It just ends up in the hands of greedy people anyway.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The government should NOT reduce spending on development aid. Development aid is important so that residents in countries in need can improve their opportunities for schooling and education, get clean water, and gain access to producing their own food. Development aid also provides the possibility of better health facilities, access to doctors, nurses, clinics, and hospitals.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The government should allocate more funds to ensure increased oil and gas extraction in the North Sea. This will reduce our dependence on other nations for oil and gas and also lower gas prices in the country. It will also strengthen our country's economy while promoting the export of materials to other countries. Bilateral trade will become stronger, and our currency will become stronger.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The government should completely scrap foreign development aid, as British tax money should go to British citizens. Globalism has destroyed our shared culture and welfare state due to corrupt and uneducated politicians who only think of themselves and the rest of the political elite. It costs too much money and human well-being for Brits to send all the money abroad. Furthermore, it is a mentally ill policy that contributes to the breakdown of British culture and traditions. The money should go exclusively to the Brits because it is for them that our ancestors paid the price. Liberate the UK and preserve our nation.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The government should impose a CO2 tax on goods so that producers make better products, allowing us to take care of each other and the climate. This should apply to everything, from the packaging of the product to how it affects the environment. The CO2 tax should make it easier for consumers to make the right choices when shopping. This applies, for example, to everything from soft drinks in plastic bottles to cigarettes, which affect the surroundings when smoked. At the same time, the tax should be lowered on fruit, vegetables, and nuts.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should impose fines on industries that pollute the environment and make it unsafe for citizens. This will also contribute to a clean country and to our economy. The government needs support from the relevant authorities and the population to make this possible. This step will also generate more revenue for the government, which can be invested in other things.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should introduce CO2 taxes on groceries and energy that pollute the most, because this will help change people's behavior in society. People need an incentive to change their behavior, and it is often monetary incentives that end up having the greatest impact. This can be seen, for example, with smoking, where rising prices have helped people quit smoking. Climate change is a serious problem that everyone has a responsibility to address. It is just not always easy for everyone to change their behavior. Therefore, a CO2 tax is a sensible tool to achieve this.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should introduce CO2 taxes on the consumption of the most polluting forms of energy, that is, energy based on fossil fuels. Here, I am mainly thinking of the industry's consumption of CO2-intensive forms of energy. This will force them to find and switch to more CO2-friendly forms of energy. Those who disagree with me should focus on the fact that it is others, not the consumers, who should pay for the production's burdensome use of fossil energy sources.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should introduce a CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most, in order to reduce emissions. It’s a choice between “ugh, now beef is a bit more expensive” and “ugh, my great-grandchildren have no planet.” In reality, we don’t have a choice — either we do something NOW, or soon it will be too late, and the climate impact can’t be stopped. Taxes work. People make choices based on prices. In addition, the revenue from the taxes could be used to combat the negative effects of CO2. There will still be cheap alternatives for people with low incomes — better for the environment, better for them.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should not introduce CO2 taxes on groceries and energy that pollute the most, as we should instead focus on making sustainable initiatives attractive. The government should instead focus on what it takes to get people to buy more sustainable groceries and more sustainable energy solutions. This could be through a reduction of taxes on sustainable solutions or perhaps a reward for choosing more sustainable options (in the form of increased tax deductions). I believe the government distances itself from the population if it taxes people too much.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should punish all industries that pollute the environment in the UK. Brits deserve a clean environment, and any company operating in the country and emitting toxic substances should be held accountable. Pollutants in the atmosphere should be taxed and severely penalized. The relevant authorities should have the mandate to enforce the rules so that these industries can comply with them.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The government should reduce spending on development aid.  The UK is not a charity organization and should focus fully on its own people and affairs. We owe these other countries nothing. The government should focus on improving the standard of living for all Brits. We need to take care of our own affairs before we help other people.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The government should take action immediately. Possibly in cooperation with other EU states/countries. We need to make ourselves as independent as possible from other countries' gas and oil production. Partly to ensure a reasonable price for oil and gas, and partly because we must acknowledge that war and sanctions from the supplying countries have a major impact on both prices and supplies.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The government should take better care of our economy in the UK. The first priorities must, above all, be ourselves here in the UK. There are cutbacks in elderly care, which has fought here in the UK to create the economy we have today. The prices of food and many other things are rising, and it affects those who do not have much to get by with. There is a lack of housing for young people who are trying to build a life here in the UK. Foreigners who come here can always get a place to live. This is not good for our new generations. Many foreigners also do not have the faith we have. They bring far too much terrorism.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The government spends several million pounds bombing countries like Iraq and Syria, etc., and now we are supporting Israel with weapons as they attempt to wipe out the Palestinians. Imagine bombs flying over your head every single day... A constant fear... a constant flight... constant killings of infants... Imagine if it were you... imagine if it were your own child. Unfortunately, we can no longer see beyond the tips of our own noses, since we ourselves live in a safe country and are safe. But a little bit of empathy and humanity could save a lot.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The only thing that can make people change their habits is hitting them in the wallet; otherwise, nothing happens. In the UK, we have the resources to take the lead in efforts to reduce CO2 emissions in the EU and to be a good example for other countries to follow. It’s not a problem to change your eating and transportation habits. Today, there are so many good, less climate-damaging alternatives that you certainly won’t suffer, even if you can’t have your steak on Saturday night or fly on vacation several times a year.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text:
The pharmaceutical industry uses an incredible amount of plastic for their products. Often, in the blister packs containing the medicine, there is a huge amount of wasted space. There is more plastic than pills!  
Here, a ban on plastic would result in lower CO2 emissions. The plastic packaging often has aluminum foil on the back, which prevents the plastic from being sorted and therefore means the packaging is sent for incineration. So a switch to, for example, glass or fiber containers for the medicine would do a lot for the environment.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text:
The price of groceries and energy has risen dramatically in recent years—so dramatically that the pension people receive is not enough to survive on, and families with children have to work so many hours that they don’t get quality time and closeness with their children.  
Instead, taxes should be imposed on all unnecessary luxury goods and all items that are not necessary for living a reasonable life.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The price of groceries and energy products has risen like never before, and many Brits are struggling to make everyday life work. The UK is already one of the countries with the highest taxes, and we do not need more. It will only become harder for the average Brit to get by. It will create a distance between Brits and the politicians, who probably do not have trouble making ends meet.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The prices of everyday goods have already increased so much that it is difficult for students and low-income families to make ends meet. By introducing additional taxes, it will likely cause more and more people to choose work over education, as it is not financially possible for them to pursue an education.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The proportion of CO2 in the atmosphere is about 0.04%, and of that 0.04%, the human-made part is about 10%, so it is an extremely small amount we are talking about. No matter what is done, it makes no difference in the grand scheme of things. We cannot change anything; everything just gets more expensive with all these taxes, and as long as Asia and South America are not involved, it is hopeless to talk about making the earth greener.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The public sector spends far too much money and resources on development aid. It’s not just about direct payments, but also about huge amounts for research and salaries. The money could be used much better elsewhere, including for our hospitals, vulnerable people, and elderly citizens in the UK. For example, we are behind on publicly allocated pension payments compared to the countries we compare ourselves with.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: There are a number of reasons why I take this political stance, even though the current issues in the world could support an opposing argument. The UK has always been a pioneering country and has valued what is ethically right higher than economic progress and capitalism. We are a country that focuses on values and people—not just those living now, but also those who will live here in the future. That is why it is important to continue to maintain our focus on the further development of green energy, so there is a future for the people, rather than succumbing to the temptation of oil and gas in the North Sea.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: There are plenty of other things to spend money on in our own country at the moment. the UK cannot solve all the world’s problems, especially not in countries where we cannot be sure where the money ends up or is channeled. Moreover, we are also spending a lot of resources on, for example, Ukrainian refugees, which can also be considered a kind of development aid.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: There are so many things in the UK that should be prioritized over development aid. The elderly, hospitals, nursing homes, and the police, among others. So before these are in order, no money should be spent on development aid. Get your own house in order before you start helping others. There is a great need for scaling up in the areas mentioned earlier.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text:
There are two main reasons why we should extract the gas and oil reserves found in the North Sea, but in general, it is also about becoming less dependent on gas and oil from abroad, and regardless of opinions about CO2, etc., it is not a solution to buy it from other countries:
1) Many people use gas for heating, and there is a desire to switch to district heating, but due to failed waste sorting, district heating has become far too expensive, and the costs of converting to district heating are also very high. 2) We are unlikely to become independent of fossil-fueled vehicles for many decades to come – so pump it up.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: There is a limited amount of oil and gas on our planet. Extracting them for our own use in the UK could ensure energy independence for a period, but the gas and oil fields will run out in the long run. Furthermore, the EU, UN, and others will increasingly call for a shift from oil and gas to alternative energy sources. Promoting oil and gas extraction in the UK would be a step in the wrong direction, both in terms of our climate goals and the world’s development. To ensure lasting, stable, and sustainable energy independence, the government should promote green initiatives such as wind, solar, or wave energy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: There is no such thing as CO2. All the CO2 we have emitted into the atmosphere since the time of the dinosaurs could fit on the tip of a pin. Therefore, debates about CO2 make no sense, and buying CO2 quotas is just a big scam. You can't buy CO2. Those who buy CO2 quotas are being cheated. Therefore, you also can't limit the emission of CO2. It makes no sense.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: There is not much logic in introducing CO2 taxes on groceries. It only leads to higher prices and more pressure for wage increases, to the detriment of our competitiveness compared to other countries, and at the same time it will result in more imports of groceries to the disadvantage of our own companies. Unfortunately, the additional CO2 emissions from transportation are not included in our CO2 accounts, which would significantly change the picture. Furthermore, these imports are almost certainly not produced as climate-friendly as our own production of the same goods.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: There should be a CO2 tax on groceries, as a large part of CO2 emissions comes from our daily consumption. There should be higher prices on products that burden the climate. The prices will force most people to pay more attention to shopping more sustainably or to find other alternatives for the products that impact the climate. Many people most likely do not consider the CO2 footprint, or how much water has been used to produce the groceries we buy. The price increase would make people more aware, so we can make choices and act more sustainably.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Think about how good we have it in our little "paradise," and how terribly many people, through no fault of their own, are suffering. We simply have to do something about it and share what we have in abundance. As human beings, we also have a shared responsibility toward our fellow man, and we must show love and take action. Every action is positive, so even a little help matters.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: This is due to unrest in the world, and therefore it is not known how sustainable our energy sources are – this could be fatal. If we do not have a safety net, we will be left without energy sources. We are such a modern society that we are dependent on having energy. In addition, it is a relatively local energy source.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: To better understand what development aid actually is, I read up on it, and I was quite surprised to learn that the UK is one of the countries that pays the most in development aid relative to its gross national income. In light of that, I think the government should reduce spending on development aid, because there are so many areas where we need to make cuts, including in the public sector. If we have more money for us Brits, it might even end up that more people can help support in their own way.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: To ensure the best conditions for our future and for future generations, we as a society need to take action. I think this action could take the form of, among other things, an extra charge on the goods that pollute the most and are most harmful to our environment. In this way, people are also nudged to make better choices or simply pay more (I also think this extra payment should go to a good cause). Action is needed, and this could be an excellent opportunity.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: To promote the UK and the Brits to avoid being dependent on various dictatorships — Russia and the Arab countries — and so that we keep British money in the country. We cannot see that we are yet at the point where we can live off wind and solar energy alone, so in order to maintain industry with cheap energy and heat.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: To secure a future, we should act now. What are a couple of tough years with taxes compared to disasters? A tax doesn’t have to be permanent. It’s a simple method to create new frameworks. Frameworks that better protect our health, both in relation to nature and the healthcare system. There are already people who can’t afford, for example, meat; so why not make it equal for everyone?
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Today we know that the use of fossil energy is the main cause of increasing CO2 pollution and the resulting temperature rises across the globe. We cannot stop this development in the next 30 years. Nor can we cover all of Funen with solar panels and Jutland with wind turbines. However, we should make every effort to research and develop alternative forms of energy—and in particular nuclear energy, which is presumably the cleanest and safest form of energy that can help solve the world’s energy problems in the long term.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Try to imagine if you were in the same situation yourself – the UK was attacked, and you had no choice but to flee the country. Wouldn’t you yourself appreciate if another country opened up and showed hospitality to you and your family? If another person showed compassion and care in what is probably one of the worst situations one can face – being chased out of your home! These are people. Children, young people, adults, the elderly. All with feelings and physical needs – something as simple as food, water, and a roof over their heads should be a right for everyone. Especially in a situation like this.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: Use of purification technologies to achieve cleaner water and reduce harmful substances in drinking water by using membranes for filtration to ensure cleaner water now and in the future. By applying this technology, water quality is improved, and there will be 98% fewer substances such as PFAS and nitrate in the water. This is done by examining different methods and designs and finding the one that best suits your treatment plant.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Use the money for the elderly, the healthcare system, and the school system. It doesn't help to give them more money. They just live off handouts from the whole world, and it's been like that for so many decades, and it's just not getting any better. Because all they've learned is to cry for help. They don't want to do anything, because it's easier to show sick children.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We all know how our planet, Earth, is suffering from our CO2 emissions! Unfortunately, we are seeing, among other things: higher temperatures (extreme heatwaves), violent, powerful storms and more extreme rainfall, rising sea levels and melting ice (the heat causes the ice sheets and glaciers to melt), coral reefs and marine species dying. That’s why it’s important that we act now and introduce CO2 taxes on groceries and energy that pollute the most, in order to reduce emissions. Don’t you also want to give your children and grandchildren a safe place to live? Namely, our wonderful Earth.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We are currently facing a climate crisis, which is evident, among other things, in more frequent natural disasters around the world. To slow down this development, we need to reduce our CO2 emissions. As an individual, one cannot make a big difference, so it is necessary to take action at the political level, where real changes can be made in society. For example, through a tax that can encourage producers and consumers to choose greener solutions. Experiences from other countries show that such a tax quickly reduces emissions without hindering economic growth.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We consumers pay so many extra taxes on everything from chocolate to cars—so much more than in any other country. We are under a lot of pressure, and many people are genuinely struggling to make ends meet. Why should we, as one of the only populations in the world, have to pay so much extra out of our own pockets, and by the way, with money that’s already been taxed, while the rest of the world gets away with it and is laughing at us?
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We give far too much money to others and forget that there are actually many people who need help here at home. We can't just give to others and then forget ourselves. It's only when everyone here gets the help they need that we can start giving to others. As a relatively small country, we can't help the rest of the world.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We have plenty of areas in the UK where there is a lack of money for good solutions. I think we should focus on those first, before we help in other countries. One question could be: Would you rather ensure good conditions for your aging grandmother or a grandmother you don’t know at all in a completely different country? The answer is obvious, unless you really hate your grandmother.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We have plenty of oil and gas resources in the North Sea, so why not make use of them instead of buying from abroad? If we utilize our own oil and gas reserves, we will also have greater security of supply. It will create more jobs and thus more tax revenue for the state and municipalities. Disadvantages: None. So just get started.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We have plenty of problems in the UK that we should spend our tax money on—primarily in the healthcare sector. The problem is that the government would rather spend money on 'prestige' projects like bridges—and then there isn’t enough left for healthcare, education, public transport (which should be free—or at least much, much cheaper). Sending money to other countries—well, companies get plenty of prestige from that when there are various fundraising campaigns on TV and so on. This isn’t a particularly good argument for changing people’s minds, but it’s my opinion—and not to win 800 kroner (a completely crazy idea in a survey).
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We have plenty of taxes in the UK! Taxes will always hit the people who don’t have much in their daily lives, whereas those who can afford it don’t change their consumption. The government has currently changed the law on social support, which has meant that many people with mental and physical illnesses have experienced a huge drop in income. Why should we kick people who are already down? But the UK is fantastic at providing support outside of the UK. Of course we should support beyond our country’s borders, but not at the expense of the quality of life for our own fellow citizens.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We have spent a lot of money on development aid for many, many years, and by and large it hasn’t helped much. Many developing countries have not progressed. There still isn’t proper democracy, and many developing countries still have corruption and poor healthcare coverage. All the money we send doesn’t help. We could use that money here at home to promote health and elderly care. We could help refugees who have to flee from war. We could research the green transition and establish wind farms or other forms of energy, so we are not dependent on energy from Russia or others. We could expand our defense.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We have wars here and there in the world... It pollutes like crazy – and the "world" can't agree. So why should the UK (which is just a few grains of sand on a huge beach compared to the world) start introducing a tax? It doesn't make any sense at all – but it will affect our fantastic country and its population.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We hear time and again that the government has found another large sum of billions, so there is plenty of money in the coffers. In addition, we are in need of extra labor anyway. People fleeing leave everything behind — jobs, homes, perhaps children and other family members; they may be traumatized, hungry, and undoubtedly distressed about what the future will bring. I think we should welcome them to our country and show them some humanity, warmth, and understanding. Isn’t that what you would hope for and wish, if it were you and your family who had to flee?
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We know that psychiatry and the municipalities lack funds. There is insufficient support for the many people in the UK who are psychologically vulnerable, ill, or disabled, and who have great difficulty functioning in daily life, resulting in poor quality of life. The country faces major challenges in having the finances, abilities, and resources to help and support its current residents. Other countries have limitations on how many refugees they accept. One must live up to the responsibility the country has taken on and help those who lack support and who are already staying in the country or are residing here.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text:
We must behave properly, take responsibility, and help our fellow human beings, and the UK has the money to do so.  
Of course, the best thing is if we can do it in their local area—but as things are right now in both Gaza and Ukraine, this is not always possible—so we have to help them here. It is, of course, important that we try to integrate them as well as possible, and in cases where this does not succeed, we must face the consequences and "ask"—read: send—them to return home again.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text:
We need people from outside, as we cannot "produce" enough people ourselves for the jobs where there is a shortage. That is why we want to keep jobs in the UK, and this concerns many of the areas that are currently affected.
In this way, we can maintain the culture, etc., that we want to have, and also expand the initiatives and develop our society as we wish.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We need to be independent of Russian gas so we don’t send money they can use for weapons of war. You can’t possibly disagree with that. Maybe we should also use wind energy. We have to be independent, otherwise they control prices/economy, so we need to be self-sufficient and keep jobs in the UK.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We need to do this to secure ourselves in the future, for more and better security, for the economy, and hopefully for a greater chance to reduce breakdowns and repair them if they occur – and to keep ourselves stable and independent without relying on others. It can save us some money and provide a healthier, better economy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We need to extract energy from the sea to be independent. The extraction will make the UK a richer country. People will live better. We will not be dependent on suppliers like Russia. This is the most important thing for our country’s economy. We must support this development strategy for the UK. That’s what I think.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We need to have better control over our own finances before we give to others. Once we have that under control, we can give more without any problems. Right now, the price of everything we give is that something has to be cut back here in the country. If we give 1 million to Uganda, we might be taking a million from the elderly or from those on student grants. We need to get to a point where we have a surplus of a million and can choose whether it should go to more here at home or abroad.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We need to help other people escape all the horrors they experience, and then we need to find them a job so they have something else to think about, not just sit in an asylum center and watch. After all, we need their labor. And then we should help them return when the opportunity arises. If there are some who have integrated well into British culture, they should be allowed to stay if they wish.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We need to promote gas and oil production so that we are not dependent on other nations' raw materials, and so that the development of green energy can "keep up." We have seen far too many examples that show this is not the path we should take; it leads to far too great costs when we create vulnerable grid networks across all of Europe.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
We need to secure the energy supply when wind and solar are not sufficient.  
We must make ourselves 100% independent of foreign actors in the energy sector—especially make ourselves independent of Russian gas, which we receive via Germany. The gas and oil supply, especially from the North Sea, is less vulnerable to sabotage than the corresponding supply via the Baltic Sea. We can extract oil and gas a bit more "environmentally friendly" than many other countries, and most of the money stays in the state treasury.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We need to take some measures against climate change because the population is not actively participating in this themselves. The government needs to introduce a CO2 tax on the groceries and energy that pollute the most in order to reduce emissions. In this way, the individual consumer is forced to make an active choice—either reduce it or pay the price for it. This can, in the long run, change the population’s habits and consumption.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We need to think about ourselves before we start thinking about everyone else. The UK is not a huge country and cannot feed the rest of the world. The more money we spend on other countries, the richer they become and the more these countries are governed by corruption — but the government refuses to see that. For them, there is prestige in giving away as much as possible and letting the weak, sick, elderly, and disabled suffer in our country, since they cannot get the help we pay overpriced taxes and VAT for.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text:
We need to think about the next generations, who should also be able to live a good and healthy life. What will your children and grandchildren think of you if you did not want to help ensure good living conditions for them, both physically and financially?

Things are already going wrong in many places on earth with hunger and the exhaustion of the soil, with drought and large wildfires and temperatures that keep breaking one record after another.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We owe it to the British people to do our best for ourselves. Our citizens work hard to create a good country, and therefore we also deserve that when things get tough, help is available, and that one can expect that their children and other young and vulnerable people will be helped. The UK is a wonderful country, but it is also important that we take care of it and do not ruin it.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We should promote the extraction of gas and oil so that we don't have to be "nice" to Putin or oil sheikhs. Dependence on such people cannot be reconciled with the UK's view of humanity or, in particular, its view of women. I can easily equate Putin with Muslim men, as neither of them has respect for viewpoints other than their own.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We should rather help our elderly citizens and spend the money on local healthcare services/hospitals. Our money is drowning in a big hole in the subsidy jungle in developing countries. Better to provide more information to citizens locally. We ourselves have so many faltering expenses and shortcomings in the UK that need to be addressed first, before we set out to save the whole world.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We should reduce development aid and focus on the elderly sector and the education system in our own country, because it is absolutely necessary. It is time to look inward at our own system and address the shortcomings in the elderly sector and in the education system. For far too long, we have given to the whole world without focusing on our own necessities.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We should use our own resources, first and foremost to be independent of Putin, but also for the sake of transport costs, and finally it can create some British jobs. We become less dependent on foreign countries and not as vulnerable to natural or man-made disasters. If we do not want to use the oil and gas we have in our own backyard, we must introduce nuclear power.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We simply can’t manage without electricity. To get water, we also need electricity to bring the water to our taps, and we sure can’t live without water. The sick can’t be treated with medicine that isn’t handmade, like when I was a student. They can’t be operated on either. Raw materials/finished goods can neither be produced nor transported. No baths and no heat in the winter.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We talk a lot about the balance between the consumer’s and the government’s responsibility to act in the climate crisis. Many consumers find it hopeless and pointless to change their behavior for the sake of the climate when they simultaneously see their fellow citizens’ shopping carts, full of CO2-intensive goods, next to their own. With an initiative from the government, people are guided to change their behavior. Here, climate consciousness does not depend on individual consumers and their green hearts, but rather it is advocated that we as citizens can join forces and act within the framework of the climate crisis.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: When even an old guy like me can see that things are really bad with the environment and pollution/global warming, then someone as smart as you should probably also be able to see the sense in the idea that it would be a good way to get people to understand the importance of doing something. And then the money can also be used for, for example, welfare—which we also lack funds for.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: When we have a problem with CO2 changing our climate, making it harder for our descendants (grandchildren) to find a good place to live in the future, it seems wrong not to account for something that contributes to that change. It is strange that it can be profitable to produce a product in one place, transport it to another place to sell it, and on the way back bring a similar product, which is then to be sold in the original place.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: When you look at how we treat our own people, I simply don’t understand how we can send so much money out of our country when we can’t help British children, young people, the elderly, and all the vulnerable in our society here at home. You can’t get appointments with a psychologist or get assessed for anything at all. The elderly and sick can’t get help with anything or get anything decent to eat, and then prices are raised on everything with more and more taxes. But money can be sent out of the country, politicians can get higher salaries while everyone else can’t make ends meet.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: With a reduction, conditions worsen in the affected countries. In the worst case, we risk unprecedented migrations, as people need food and shelter. The absolute cheapest way to achieve these things is to help where people live. When the harvest fails due to drought or rain, the international community must step in—also in its own interest.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: With new studies showing that fewer clouds are forming, climate change is already more severe than initially assumed. Therefore, more political responsibility should be taken to reduce the harmful effects as much as possible. A tax on the most CO2-emitting goods and energy could slow down the changes, as consumers would choose a cheaper alternative. This is already seen in the decline in beef sales as well as producers’ initiatives to mix the climate-damaging beef with less climate-damaging meat from pigs and poultry.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: With the experiences from the energy crisis that arose in connection with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, we were painfully reminded of how vulnerable we are. Both in terms of dependence on other nations—especially those with whom real negotiations are not possible—and because of the new phenomenon of energy sabotage (cutting of pipelines, etc.). the UK’s “operations” are, so to speak, dependent on a stable energy supply, both at the individual, business, and societal level, which is why it is obvious that we should make ourselves less vulnerable. Moreover, it generates jobs in the energy sector, which is also positive.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Yes, the UK should develop oil, gas, etc. itself in order not to be dependent on other countries and pay higher prices for others’ gas, oil, etc. Otherwise, it will become expensive for all Brits. So it’s clear that we in the UK should use as much as we can of our large resources of oil and gas, etc., so that it doesn’t become expensive.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: the UK already receives too many asylum seekers, who turn out to be very difficult to integrate. However, I am open to the UK receiving asylum seekers who share British values and do not try to change our society. Unfortunately, people with a Muslim background all too often do not live up to the above, and therefore they should not be granted asylum.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: the UK and other countries have paid enormous sums to developing countries for decades, but it has hardly made any difference—in fact, the money has enabled many countries to maintain unhealthy and unsustainable societies. It would help much more to focus on increased trade and education in the countries in question.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: the UK is already one of the countries that pays the most for development aid, and since there are several areas that are lagging behind in the UK, it is there that more of the available resources should be allocated, such as the school system, hospitals, and elderly care. It is hard to see the UK as a welfare society when we cannot take care of our own but spend the money incorrectly.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: the UK is perfectly capable of receiving more people who are fleeing from war or persecution. In my opinion, we are actually obligated to do so, because all people, young and old, should be able to live a dignified life with security, opportunities, and rights. As the wealthy welfare state that the UK is, we should not just wait passively while the EU legislates and distributes asylum seekers—which is, by the way, an important and necessary process—but we need to welcome with open arms those people and families who are fleeing north. No one flees for fun. It is an act of solidarity to give someone a chance to build a new life.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: the UK is vulnerable when it comes to oil and gas supplies. We should do everything we can and are able to do to make the UK as self-sufficient as possible, since unfortunately we live in a troubled world. Oil and gas supplies are an important weapon against the UK in turbulent times, as we are dependent on being able to buy and, not least, transport them from other countries. Therefore, the government should concentrate its efforts and prioritize this.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: the UK should make use of the oil and natural gas in the North Sea so that the UK and Europe are as independent as possible from other countries' oil and gas production. Until it is possible to manage 100% with alternative energy, which could also include nuclear power plants, since solar and wind energy are not completely stable. And it also helps to maintain a more stable price level.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: the UK should receive more asylum seekers, as it is inhumane to reject people who are forced to flee their own country due to war, persecution, etc. Allowing them to seek asylum is the least bit of respect we can show them after they have gone through what must be assumed to be a frightening and degrading escape.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: the UK will continue to use fossil fuels for many years to come, even though there are massive investments in green energy. Therefore, the UK should continue to promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea. In this way, the UK can be less dependent on, for example, Arab countries. This will promote an independent foreign policy towards these regimes.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.
